latest news.eng_title: Boeing Starliner prepares to leaves space station empty, months later than planned
latest news.summary: Boeing's Starliner spacecraft is set to leave the International Space Station on Friday, months later than planned, without the two astronauts it carried into orbit. The capsule will return to Earth in about six hours and land at White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico. NASA test pilots Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams will stay at the ISS for the rest of the year and return to Earth in February aboard SpaceX's Dragon spacecraft. The return of Boeing's Starliner capsule 'Calypso' ends a test flight that was much longer than initially predicted, with Boeing investigating an issue with the capsule's thrusters for three months. NASA officials decided to send Starliner back empty to 'further understand the root causes' of the spacecraft's issues, which could threaten Boeing's future involvement in NASA's Commercial Crew program.
latest news.title: Boeing Starliner prepares to leaves space station empty, months later than planned

latest news.eng_title: Boeing Starliner to Return to Earth Without Crew
latest news.summary: After 12 weeks in space, the Boeing Starliner spacecraft is set to return to Earth on September 6, 2024, without its two-person crew. The spacecraft is scheduled to separate from the orbital laboratory at 6:00 PM Eastern Time and spend about 6 hours maneuvering closer to Earth before landing at the White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico around midnight. If all goes as planned, Starliner will land under parachutes in White Sands, New Mexico, a few minutes after midnight on Saturday. However, weather or technical issues may cause a delay in the separation or landing. The two astronauts, Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley, who were on the Starliner mission, will remain on the orbital laboratory until February 2025, when they will return on a SpaceX Crew Dragon spacecraft.
latest news.title: بدون طاقمها.. مركبة بوينغ ستارلاينر الفضائية تعود إلى الأرض الجمعة

latest news.eng_title: Boeing's Starliner will try to return to Earth today. Here's how it should unfold
latest news.summary: The Boeing Starliner spacecraft is scheduled to return to Earth on Friday without its crew, who are staying on the International Space Station until February 2025. The spacecraft will attempt to land at one of several available sites in the White Sands Missile Range, New Mexico; Willcox, Arizona; Dugway Proving Ground, Utah; or Edwards Air Force Base in California. NASA has altered the planned series of thruster firings to minimize the use of the aft-facing thrusters, which temporarily ceased operation during initial docking attempts. The spacecraft will perform a deorbit burn, lasting roughly 60 seconds, to slow down and reenter Earth's atmosphere. The deorbit burn will pose the biggest test for the mercurial thrusters, but NASA is prepared to handle any issues. After landing, several teams will move toward the spacecraft to perform recovery procedures, including sniffing the capsule for hypergolic fuels, electrically grounding and stabilizing the spacecraft, and documenting the recovery for public relations and future process review.
latest news.title: Boeing's Starliner will try to return to Earth today. Here's how it should unfold

latest news.eng_title: How Boeing's Starliner Will Make the Epic Journey Back to Earth Without Astronauts Onboard
latest news.summary: Boeing's Starliner spacecraft, called Calypso, is returning to Earth without astronauts on board. The spacecraft will undock from the International Space Station (ISS) and travel six hours to a landing site in New Mexico. NASA officials have expressed concerns about the spacecraft's propulsion system, which leaked helium and failed five thrusters during a previous test. To mitigate the risk, the spacecraft will use a faster trajectory to undock and will perform 12 thruster burns to distance itself from the ISS. The spacecraft will then perform a deorbit burn to slow down and re-enter Earth's atmosphere, where it will endure temperatures of up to 3,000 degrees Fahrenheit. The spacecraft will deploy parachutes and landing bags to slow down and cushion its touchdown. NASA officials expect the spacecraft to land at a speed of just four mph. The return of Calypso marks the end of its saga, but the future of Starliner's development remains unclear.
latest news.title: How Boeing's Starliner Will Make the Epic Journey Back to Earth Without Astronauts Onboard

latest news.eng_title: Starliner Calypso Returns to Earth Without Crew After NASA Loses Confidence
latest news.summary: The Starliner Calypso, a spacecraft developed by Boeing, is set to return to Earth without a crew after a series of delays and issues. The NASA has confirmed that the spacecraft will separate from the International Space Station (ISS) at 0:04 on Saturday and land safely at the White Sands base in New Mexico, USA, 5 hours and 59 minutes later. However, the NASA has lost confidence in the Starliner's ability to safely transport astronauts, and has decided to use a SpaceX spacecraft to bring back the two astronauts, Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, in February 2025. The decision has strained the relationship between NASA and Boeing. The Starliner's return is a crucial test for the spacecraft, and the NASA is conducting a series of tests to ensure its safety. The spacecraft's propellers have been a major concern, with several failures reported during the flight. The NASA is also investigating an unusual noise detected by the astronauts on the ISS. The noise was attributed to a faulty audio configuration between the spacecraft and the ISS. The NASA has assured that the noise has no impact on the crew or the spacecraft's operations. The Starliner's return is a significant setback for Boeing's space program, which has been plagued by delays and issues. The NASA has hinted that it will require significant changes to the spacecraft's design and operation before it can be certified for crewed missions.
latest news.title: La Starliner regresa a la Tierra sin tripulantes desde la ISS, después de fuertes tensiones entre la NASA y Boeing

latest news.eng_title: NASA's Boeing Starliner Mission Landing Criteria, Timeline
latest news.summary: NASA and Boeing are preparing to return the Starliner spacecraft uncrewed from the International Space Station to Earth. The spacecraft will land at one of several designated sites in the US, including the White Sands Missile Range, New Mexico; Willcox, Arizona; Dugway Proving Ground, Utah; and Edwards Air Force Base in California. The teams will conduct a series of checks, including weather checks, to ensure a safe landing. The Starliner will complete a series of departure burns to reach its landing site in as little as six hours. Once clear to proceed, the spacecraft will execute its deorbit burn, slowing it down enough to re-enter Earth's atmosphere. After landing, a series of teams will approach the spacecraft in a sequential order to document the recovery and prepare it for refurbishment. The spacecraft will be transferred to Boeing facilities at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida for refurbishment ahead of its next flight.
latest news.title: NASA's Boeing Starliner Mission Landing Criteria, Timeline

latest news.eng_title: Sunita Williams in space: What if Boeing's Starliner spacecraft's return to Earth is further delayed? NASA says...
latest news.summary: The Boeing Starliner spacecraft, carrying NASA astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore, is set to return to Earth on September 6. However, if the return is delayed, NASA has backup opportunities spaced four days apart, providing flexibility to ensure safe touchdown conditions. According to Anthony Vareha, flight director, International Space Station, 'we have undocking opportunities on several later days, all of which are subject to weather constraints.' Vareha added that once the hatch in the Starliner is closed on Thursday, 'we will leave it closed, no matter the undocking date.' NASA experts have full confidence in Starliner's safe return to Earth, but Vareha noted that 'we have guidance in these rules to say which types of things we can live without versus which things we would actually stop the undocking for; it's a very long rule.'
latest news.title: Sunita Williams in space: What if Boeing's Starliner spacecraft's return to Earth is further delayed? NASA says...

latest news.eng_title: Unmanned Boeing Starliner to land in New Mexico this weekend
latest news.summary: An unmanned Boeing Starliner spacecraft is set to return to Earth, landing at the White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico. The spacecraft, which was originally supposed to return with two astronauts, will undock from the International Space Station (ISS) on Friday, September 6, at 6:04 p.m. Eastern time, and land just after midnight at 12:04 a.m. Eastern time. The mission was delayed due to technical problems, including helium leaks and issues with the spacecraft's thrusters. NASA will be live streaming the undocking and landing on its website. This is not the first time White Sands has been a landing site for space missions, with Boeing successfully landing an unmanned Starliner there in 2022, and another spacecraft landing in 2019. The astronauts currently aboard the ISS, who were initially supposed to return on the Starliner, will now return on a different spacecraft in February next year.
latest news.title: Unmanned Boeing Starliner to land in New Mexico this weekend

latest news.eng_title: Sunita Williams In Space: What If Boeing's Starliner Return To Earth Is Further Delayed? NASA Says...
latest news.summary: The Boeing Starliner spacecraft, carrying NASA astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore, is scheduled to return to Earth on September 6. However, if the return is delayed, Anthony Vareha, flight director, International Space Station, stated that there are undocking opportunities on several later days, subject to weather constraints. These backup opportunities are spaced four days apart, providing flexibility to ensure safe touchdown conditions. Once the hatch in the Starliner is closed on Thursday, it will remain closed, regardless of the undocking date. 'We have undocking opportunities on several later days all of which are subject to weather constraints,' Vareha said. 'We will leave it closed, no matter the undocking date,' he added.
latest news.title: Sunita Williams In Space: What If Boeing's Starliner Return To Earth Is Further Delayed? NASA Says...

latest news.eng_title: Boeing's Starliner will be sent back to Earth soon — without its astronauts
latest news.summary: The Boeing Starliner spacecraft is scheduled to return to Earth on Friday evening, without its astronauts on board. NASA officials confirmed that the uncrewed spacecraft will depart from the International Space Station at approximately 6:04 p.m. ET and land at White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico at 12:03 a.m. on Saturday. The spacecraft's propulsion system has been experiencing issues, including thruster failures and helium leaks, which have caused delays and raised concerns about its ability to return to Earth safely. NASA has decided to use a modified flight plan to accommodate the uncrewed vessel and is anticipating a successful return. The astronauts, Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, will return to Earth on a SpaceX vehicle early next year. Boeing has been struggling with quality issues and budget overruns, and this setback is a significant blow to the company's Starliner program.
latest news.title: Boeing's Starliner will be sent back to Earth soon — without its astronauts

news knowledge.eng_title: Why are astronauts stuck in space? Starliner to head home - without its crew
news knowledge.summary: The Boeing Starliner capsule is scheduled to return to Earth without its crew, Sunita 'Suni' Williams and Barry 'Butch' Wilmore, who will stay aboard the space station until February 2025. The capsule will undock from the space station on August 29 and land at the White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico using parachutes and airbags. NASA decided to leave the astronauts behind due to helium leaks that caused the thrusters to malfunction, making the flight home unsafe. The two astronauts will return on the SpaceX Crew-9 capsule, scheduled for liftoff on September 24. The Starliner capsule has already completed two uncrewed flights, with the first one failing to reach orbit in 2019 and the second one successfully docking at the space station in 2022.
news knowledge.title: Why are astronauts stuck in space? Starliner to head home - without its crew

news knowledge.eng_title: NASA and Boeing Announce Uncrewed Return of Starliner Capsule
news knowledge.summary: NASA and Boeing announced that the uncrewed return of the Starliner capsule will take place on Friday, September 6, when it will be detached from the International Space Station and is expected to take six hours to reach Earth. However, there is still uncertainty about the success of the process, and they warned that 'there is a risk of the mechanism getting stuck.' The engineers want to recover the spacecraft to 'analyze it and find out what went wrong' and indicated that 'it was not prepared for autonomous flight' and numerous software updates were made. Even if it separates successfully, there is a risk of another failure in the propulsion system, which could cause the spacecraft to spin out of control and re-enter the atmosphere without control. Butch Wilmore, through a radio conversation with the Mission Control Center in Houston, reported that 'there is a strange noise coming from the speaker' of Starliner, which is likely to be some type of interference in the system. The news about the return of the Starliner spacecraft comes at a time when there are discussions about how to bring back astronauts Wilmore and Williams, who have been in space for 12 weeks and will continue their work on the Expedition 71/72 crew, which will depart from Earth on September 24. Once Starliner lands on Earth, the NASA plan is to disassemble it at 18:04 Eastern Time, initiate a controlled re-entry, and land it at the White Sands Spaceport in New Mexico. 'The spacecraft will touch down around 00:03 on Saturday, September 7, descending with parachutes and airbags to cushion the impact,' the US space agency reported.
news knowledge.title: La NASA y Boeing revelaron la fecha para el regreso no tripulado de la cápsula Starliner: "No estaba preparada para el vuelo autónomo"

news knowledge.eng_title: Starliner to Return to Earth Without Crew on September 6
news knowledge.summary: The NASA and Boeing have scheduled the uncrewed Starliner spacecraft to detach from the International Space Station on September 6. The Starliner launched on June 5 on its first crewed mission, carrying NASA astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore to the space station. However, the spacecraft experienced helium leaks and five of its 28 reaction control system thrusters failed during the journey to the orbiting laboratory. Following tests, it was decided to opt for an uncrewed return to avoid risks. After detaching, the Starliner will take approximately six hours to reach the landing zone at the White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico. The spacecraft will land on September 7, descending with parachutes and airbags to cushion the impact. The recovery teams at the landing site will secure and prepare the spacecraft for its return to the Boeing Starliner factory at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, according to a NASA statement. The Starliner has already successfully completed two uncrewed orbital flight tests, including a demonstration of its ability to autonomously detach from the station safely.
news knowledge.title: Starliner regresará a la Tierra sin tripulación el 6 de septiembre

news knowledge.eng_title: NASA says Boeing's Starliner will return to Earth uncrewed on Sept. 6
news knowledge.summary: NASA has announced that Boeing's Starliner spacecraft will return to Earth uncrewed on September 6, after a series of technical issues and delays. The spacecraft, which has been stranded in space since June, will perform a fully autonomous return, with flight controllers remotely commanding the spacecraft if needed. According to NASA, the Starliner will undock from the International Space Station at 6:04 p.m. EDT on September 6, and will touch down in the New Mexico landing zone at White Sands Space Harbor about six hours later. The astronauts, Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, will return to Earth on the SpaceX Crew-9 mission in February 2025, after spending at least 262 total days in orbit. NASA Administrator Bill Nelson said, 'Butch and Suni will return with Crew-9 next February.'
news knowledge.title: NASA says Boeing's Starliner will return to Earth uncrewed on Sept. 6

news knowledge.eng_title: An empty Boeing Starliner is set to return next week, while its crew stays in space
news knowledge.summary: An empty Boeing Starliner spacecraft is scheduled to return to Earth on September 6, more than 12 weeks after its initial return date. According to NASA, the spacecraft will undock from the International Space Station around 6 p.m. ET 'pending weather and operational readiness.' The Starliner will then touch down in New Mexico before returning to Boeing's factory at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Meanwhile, astronauts Barry 'Butch' Wilmore and Sunita 'Suni' Williams, who flew aboard the Starliner in June, will remain in space and return in a SpaceX capsule in February.
news knowledge.title: An empty Boeing Starliner is set to return next week, while its crew stays in space

news knowledge.eng_title: NASA and Boeing to Undock Starliner Spacecraft from Space Station
news knowledge.summary: NASA and Boeing have decided to undock the uncrewed Starliner spacecraft from the International Space Station on September 6, 2024, at around 5:45pm ET (2145 UTC). The spacecraft will then land on Earth on September 7, 2024, at around 10:03am (0403 UTC) at the White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico. This is the same spacecraft that took astronauts Sunita Williams and Barry 'Butch' Wilmore to the space station on June 5, 2024, but they have been stranded there due to technical issues. The decision to send the Starliner back to Earth empty was made after two previous accidents, the Challenger and Columbia space shuttle disasters, which killed 14 astronauts, including Indian-American Kalpana Chawla. The Starliner spacecraft has been plagued with issues since its inception, including a failed orbital maneuvering and attitude control system thrusters during a test flight in 2022. The spacecraft has been delayed multiple times, including a recent launch postponement due to a helium leak. NASA and Boeing are taking a cautious approach to ensure the safety of the astronauts on board. The spacecraft will be returned to Earth as soon as possible, and the astronauts will be safely retrieved. 'We are 'go' to proceed with undocking the uncrewed #Starliner from the @Space_Station on Friday, Sept. 6,' NASA tweeted. 'Undocking coverage is set to begin at 5:45pm ET (2145 UTC), with Starliner touching down at 12:03am (0403 UTC) on Sept. 7.'
news knowledge.title: इस तारीख को धरती पर लौटेगा सुनीता विलियम्स को स्पेस स्टेशन पर अटकाने वाला स्टारलाइनर कैप्सूल

news knowledge.eng_title: Empty Boeing Starliner spacecraft could return next week
news knowledge.summary: NASA is planning to return the uncrewed Boeing Starliner spacecraft, named Calypso, to Earth as soon as next Friday. The spacecraft launched with astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams on June 5, but due to helium leaks and thruster issues, NASA decided to bring its Crew Flight Test astronauts home on the upcoming Crew-9 mission. Dr. Ken Kremer stated, 'They're definitely going to get tons of information. They're going to find out if it really was safe to bring the astronauts home on Starliner, or if it wasn't, it was a close call.' The Crew-9 mission, including Wilmore and Williams, will remain at the space station until February 2025.
news knowledge.title: Empty Boeing Starliner spacecraft could return next week

news knowledge.eng_title: Starliner to Return to Earth Without Crew, Astronauts to Return in 2025
news knowledge.summary: The NASA and Boeing have scheduled the Starliner spacecraft to undock from the International Space Station on September 6 without its crew. The Starliner successfully completed an uncrewed orbital flight test with a successful entry and landing on two separate occasions. After undocking, the Starliner will take approximately six hours to reach the landing site at the White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico, where it will land with parachutes and airbags to cushion the impact. The spacecraft will then be secured and prepared for its return to the Boeing Starliner factory at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore will remain on the space station as part of the Expedition 71/72 crew until February 2025, when they will return with the Crew-9 mission.
news knowledge.title: Starliner regresará a la Tierra sin tripulación; Astronautas regresarán hasta 2025

news knowledge.eng_title: ‘Uncrewed' NASA Boeing Starliner ‘Calypso' to undock at International Space Station on September 6. When, where to watch
news knowledge.summary: The uncrewed NASA Boeing Starliner 'Calypso' is set to undock from the International Space Station on September 6. The spacecraft will then return to Earth, landing at White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico after a six-hour journey. NASA has confirmed that the Starliner has successfully completed two orbital flight tests, including a previous uncrewed entry and landing. The return can be watched live on the Space Affairs' YouTube channel. The spacecraft will touch down at 9:30 AM IST on September 7, descending under parachutes and with inflated airbags to cushion the impact. This comes after NASA announced that astronauts Barry Wilmore and Sunita Williams will return to Earth in a SpaceX vehicle in February next year, due to issues with the Starliner's propulsion system.
news knowledge.title: ‘Uncrewed' NASA Boeing Starliner ‘Calypso' to undock at International Space Station on September 6. When, where to watch

news knowledge.eng_title: Boeing Starliner to Return to Earth Without Astronauts on September 7
news knowledge.summary: NASA has announced the schedule for the undocking of the Boeing Starliner spacecraft from the International Space Station. According to NASA, the undocking is planned for no earlier than 18:04 Eastern European Time (19:04 Moscow Time) on Friday, September 6, 2024, weather permitting and subject to readiness for operation. The spacecraft will require approximately six hours after undocking to reach the landing zone in the White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico. If all goes as planned, the Starliner is expected to land on parachutes at 12:03 (13:03 Moscow Time) on Saturday, September 7. Rescue teams at the landing site will secure and prepare the spacecraft for its return to the Boeing Starliner factory at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. As a reminder, NASA announced on August 24 that the Starliner would return to Earth without a crew. The mission team had to update the Starliner's systems to enable a return in an unmanned mode. As a result, the Starliner will perform a fully autonomous return under the guidance of flight controllers at the Starliner Mission Control Center in Houston and the Boeing Mission Control Center in Florida. Ground teams can remotely control the spacecraft if necessary. The Boeing Starliner spacecraft was previously crewed by NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams, who launched to the station on the spacecraft in June 2024. Wilmore and Williams will remain on board the orbital complex until February 2025 and will return on the NASA Crew-9 mission.
news knowledge.title: NASA определилось: Boeing Starliner вернется на Землю без астронавтов 7 сентября
